title: Can a Christian challenge Christianity and a Muslim challenge Islam? - Quora

response.answer_text: If by “Christianity” and “Islam” you mean the traditions of the Church/Mosque that are contradictory to the teachings within their respective Holy texts, then yes. I am a Christian. There are many traditions held by different denominations, even within my own denomination, that I consider unfaithful to the teachings of Christ and God’s word. Only through regular studies of each tradition can I know if they actually are contrary to scripture. There’s one I’m currently studying in order to discuss it with my senior pastor, and yes he is aware of my objection. A Christian shouldn’t actively seek out the false doctrines, but should be studying the word of God to know what it teaches, and closely paying attention to the teachings of their pastors/teachers. If they perceive that the pastor/teacher is straying from scriptural truth, they should privately approach the teacher to address the teaching. This needs to be done tactfully and with a mind open to the possibility that they might be wrong. There is a process in the Bible that can be used for this. However, if a person calls themselves a Christian, but challenges the central doctrines of Christianity (the death and resurrection of Christ, the identity of Christ… meaning the second person of the trinity that is the one and only God… etc)… and I’m referring only to the biblical teachings on those, not someone’s (mis)understanding of the biblical teachings… then that person ceases to be a Christian. If you are worshipping anything or anyone other than the one true God, then you are engaging in idolatry.

Christianity is a frail and decaying faith in terms of the amount of believers it has. The West is becoming increasingly atheistic or twisting their Christian texts to fit evolving socially left wing political agendas. Islam is a far more powerful and fast growing religion. Although officially Christianity is the largest religion in the world on paper, Islam probably has a far greater amount of true believers. Also the penatly for leaving Islam is far more serious than for leaving Christianity in any area of the world. Whether that be punishment by the government or by the family.
